origination.corpname: University of Michigan. Senate. Advisory Committee on University Affairs.

did.unittitle: Senate Advisory Committee on University Affairs (University of Michigan) records 1937-1996 1960-1995
did.abstract: The Senate Advisory Committee on University Affairs (SACUA) serves as the executive body of the University of Michigan Senate. SACUA represents the faculty as a whole in its work on University policy and its power to nominate faculty to governance committees. The records consist of documents generated by SACUA and its committees. The bulk of the material originates from SACUA's committees and includes work on academic affairs, affirmative action, faculty grievance procedures, research, student quality, and tenure.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: Records are transferred in periodic accessions by the Senate Advisory Committee on University Affairs (Donor # 5029 and # 8656).

accessrestrict.p: The Senate Advisory Committee for University Affairs records are open for research except for certain records restricted by statute or university policy. Restricted material includes personnel-related files, including search, review, promotion, and tenure files; student educational records; client/patient records; and records of executive officers of the university.

The SACUA record group includes restricted material in the following categories:
Personnel Related Records -- Boxes 11-12

userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to the Board of Regents of the University of Michigan

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Senate Advisory Committee on University Affairs (University of Michigan) Records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Since its creation in 1937, the Senate Advisory Committee on University Affairs (SACUA) has played a major role in faculty governance. In his report "Faculty Governance at the University of Michigan," historian Nicholas Steneck defines faculty governance as "the means by which the Regents and their designated representatives provide some self government to, seek advice from, and ask for consent from the faculty." In the 19th century, faculty governance was the responsibility of the University Senate, a body made up of the entire faculty. By the early 20th century, the university had outgrown this system of governance: the increased number of faculty made the Senate unmanageably large, and did not reflect the growing importance of professional administrators. These inadequacies led to a series of reorganizations of faculty governance. In 1906, the powers of the Senate were transferred to a smaller executive body called the Senate Council. In 1931, the Senate Council was replaced with another body called the University Council, which included both faculty and professional administrators.

By 1937, the University Council proved to be too large, and SACUA was created to represent the Senate in the University Council and to report to the Senate. At this stage, SACUA consisted of some members elected by the Senate and others chosen by the Dean's Conference. In 1940, the importance of SACUA was diminished with the creation of another executive governing body, the Advisory Board on University Policies. The new body was appointed by the Board of Regents, and therefore weakened faculty control over university governance. By 1948, the University Council had ceded most of its functions to these smaller executive bodies, and was dissolved. That same year, SACUA was restructured to serve as the executive body of the Senate, with members elected at large by the Senate. In 1965, the University Senate again reorganized faculty governance by creating a body called the Senate Assembly. The new body consisted of sixty-five members elected to represent the various colleges and schools of the university. The Assembly served as the legislative arm of the Senate and elected the members of SACUA. Presently, SACUA continues to serve as an executive arm of the Senate Assembly. It consists of nine members elected for three year terms. In addition to their duties as executives of the Senate, the members of SACUA are responsible for nominating faculty members to various governance committees.

scopecontent.p: The Senate Advisory Council on University Affairs Records consist of correspondence, minutes, and reports relating primarily to the economic status of the faculty and the administration of the University. The records measure 12.5 linear feet and range from 1937-1996, the bulk of which spans 1960-1995. The records are arranged in four series: Minutes; Core Records; Boards, Committees and Commissions and Photographs.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.subject: Teacher participation in administration--Michigan--Ann Arbor.
controlaccess.corpname: University of Michigan. Committee on the Economic Status of the Faculty.
University of Michigan. Senate. Advisory Committee on University Affairs.

scopecontent.p: The Minutes series, 1937-1995 (1.25 linear feet) consists of minutes from SACUA meetings from 1937 to 1995, mostly in binders. The minutes include brief reports from SACUA committees, and cover a wide range of subjects, such as faculty pay and benefits, educational policy, campus planning, and student relations.

The Core Records series contains material generated by SACUA itself, as opposed to its committees or subcommittees. The core records series includes correspondence, chairman's papers, documents on tenure and grievance cases, and SACUA reports on a variety of subjects. The series also contains a folder of material explaining the structure of SACUA and the Senate Assembly, which might help researchers to understand the structure of faculty governance.

did.unittitle: Faculty Perspectives article with George Brewer 1995

odd.p: (reports explaining the structure and procedures of faculty governance)

scopecontent.p: The Boards, Committees and Commissions series, 1957-1995 (6.5 linear feet) represent the records of the various organizations that report through SACUA to the Senate. Interesting records include the Board in Control of Intercollegiate Athletics, the Committee on the Economic Status of the Faculty (CESF), and the Committee for a Multicultural University. CESF reports are particularly valuable because of their annual reports discussing faculty compensation. The Bylaws/Rules Committee subseries, 1959-1997 (.25 linear feet) consists of bound correspondence and reports surrounding the formation of policy for the senate and the university, including rules governing the makeup of the senate's governing bodies and the demographics of the university faculty. The Bylaws Committee changes its name to the Rules Committee in December 1977. The Grievance Subcommittee subseries, 1983-1996 (.75 linear feet) contains correspondence, reports, and research information pertaining to the university grievance policy. This material was part of an accession from Professor Thomas E. Moore, who served on SACUA, the Grievance Subcommittee, and was president of the University of Michigan chapter of the American Association of University Professors (AAUP).
